diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
justification: Kawasaki disease commonly presents with fever, conjunctivitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, hand erythema, and can also cause sterile pyuria.}, {diagnosis: Urinary tract infection (UTI)
justification: Pyuria and fever are hallmark symptoms of a UTI.}, {diagnosis: Adenovirus infection

justification: Adenovirus can cause a wide range of symptoms, including conjunctivitis, fever, pharyngitis (which can lead to cervical lymphadenopathy), and sometimes urinary tract involvement.}, {diagnosis: Viral infection (non-specific)
justification: Many viral infections can cause a combination of fever, conjunctivitis, and lymphadenopathy.}, {diagnosis: Streptococcal infection (including scarlet fever)

justification: Streptococcal infections can cause fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a rash that can resemble hand erythema. Some strains can also cause conjunctivitis.}, {diagnosis: Mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus)
justification: Mononucleosis often presents with fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and sometimes conjunctivitis.}, {diagnosis: Measles
justification: Measles typically presents with fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a rash. Cervical lymphadenopathy can also occur.}, {diagnosis: Drug reaction
justification: Some drug reactions can cause a combination of fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and lymphadenopathy.}, {diagnosis: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA)
justification: While less common, some forms of JIA can present with fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and lymphadenopathy.}, {diagnosis: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

justification: SLE is a multisystem autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fever, rash, conjunctivitis, lymphadenopathy, and sometimes kidney involvement that could lead to pyuria.}

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Vitamin deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12, vitamin D)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Pulmonary Embolism (unlikely given normal pulmonary function tests, but should be considered)
Asthma (unlikely given normal pulmonary function tests, but should be considered)
Vitamin deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin D, Vitamin B12)
Chronic kidney disease with a systemic manifestation
Side effects of medications (e.g., corticosteroids, immunosuppressants)
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) (Crohns disease or ulcerative colitis)
Multiple myeloma (rare, but can cause bone pain and leukocytosis)
Autoimmune disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Mood Disorders (e.g., Bipolar Disorder, Major Depressive Disorder)
Hashimotos thyroiditis (in the early, hyperthyroid phase)
Substance use disorder (e.g., stimulants, cocaine, amphetamines)
Withdrawal syndromes (e.g., alcohol withdrawal, benzodiazepine withdrawal)
Autonomic dysfunction (e.g., postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS))
Medications side effects (e.g., steroids, decongestants, antidepressants)
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) - Crohns disease or ulcerative colitis
Anxiety (in some cases, anxiety can cause gastrointestinal symptoms)

Common cold (though diarrhea is less common)
